Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Approximation Algorithms and Topological Graph Theory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Large and complex interconnected systems have become ubiquitous in the modern world, from science and engineering, to finance and commerce. In many scenarios, the structure of such systems is modeled by networks of interacting entities. This modeling paradigm can be used when studying a plethora of natural objects and phenomena, such as the web, networks of all kinds - social, transportation, communication, phylogenetic - financial transactions, and so on. The analysis of large and complex networks is therefore a task of increasing importance to society. However, reaping the potential benefits from the analysis of these objects poses great new challenges for computational sciences. Even though the statistical analysis of interconnected structures has been the subject of intense study for several decades, many of the current methods are inadequate for modern data sets. At the high level, there are two main reasons for this inadequacy. 

First, a key task in the analysis of networks is the discovery of useful structure. That is, finding a network representation that reveals useful information. For example, when studying a social network, it can be useful to know whether specific patterns occur in the sets of friendships between users. Unfortunately, the increasing ability to record large amounts of data has given rise to networks of unprecedented size. As a consequence, methods that were originally designed for discovering structures in smaller networks, require prohibitively large amounts of computational resources to be useful in these scenarios. Second, having discovered some useful structure in a network, it is often desirable to exploit it through further computations. For example, given a transportation network with a certain topology, one might want to design shipping methods that take advantage of this structure. Performing such computations has become exceedingly intractable in real-world data sets due to the fact that contemporary networks exhibit structure of increasingly high complexity. Many current methods for exploiting network structure are only applicable to cases of moderate complexity, and are therefore inapplicable.

This project investigates new methods for discovering and exploiting structure in networks of large size, and large complexity. The research effort will focus on designing new algorithms for these two classes of problems using ideas from the so-called theory of approximation algorithms. These are algorithms that aim to allow a small amount of error, in exchange for significantly better computational performance. Existing work on this type of algorithm suggests that this is a promising direction for overcoming the barriers of network size and complexity outlined above. 

Broader impacts of the project include graduate training and the development of a new graduate course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The analysis of large and complicated data sets is a task of central importance in several areas of science and engineering. In many application domains, our increased ability to monitor and record information has given rise to a plethora of data sets that encode reationships and interactions between vast amounts of interconnected objects. Prototypical examples of such objects include users in a social network, nodes in a communication network, neurons in a brain, geographic locations on a map, and so on. The most common way to mathematically model such data is using graphs. Under this interpretation, several data-analytic tasks can be cast as graph-theoretic algorithmic problems. The project explored various fundamental questions of this nature using tools from the theories of topological graph theory and approximation algorithms. Several new algorithms were developed, achieving faster performance and significnaly lower error guarantees than what was previously known.

A main effort of the project was the development of algorithms for computing various topological parameters of graphs, including genus, crossing number, and related notions that quantify the topological complexity of a network. The study of these topological parameters has a long history spanning several decades. Most problems related to computing these quantities exactly are known to be intractable, and thus the project has focused on deriving algorithms with provable better error guarantees. These new algorithms achieve exponential improvements on the error bounds compared to the previously best-known results. For some of these problems the project derived the first non-trivial efficient algorithms.

Apart from discovering interesting topological structures in networks, the project also focused on exploiting these properties in the design of improved algorithms. The mathematical tools developed in the project have also lead to improved algorithms for problems in the analysis of parallel systems with multi-level memory hierarchies, routing in communication networks, and for classical optimization tasks such as the Traveling Salesperson Problem (TSP) on networks with specific topological properties.

The study of the above problems has lead to new connections between mathematics and computer science. Specifically, the project developed computationally efficient variants of tools that were originally used in the graph minor theory. Moreover, the project discovered connections between certain measures of topological complexity of networks and notions of fractal dimension, which quantifies the complexity of geometric objects. This new connection leads to further transfer of ideas between algorithmic graph theory and computational geometry.

The results of the project have improved our ability to compute important topological properties of networks. They have also lead to new and improved algorithms in diverse domains that exploit the topological structure of graphs. The mathematical tools developed have formed new connections between algorithm design, graph theory, and geometry. The problems studied in the project formed the basis in the training of graduate and undergraduate students, who acquired skills on the design of efficient algorithmic methods with provable guarantees.
